item.title: The Democratic shutdown gambit
item.description: At least 10 Republican senators are willing to extend Affordable Care Act subsidies in some form.

item.title: Elon Musk’s trillion-dollar payday
item.description: There are plenty of reasons to root for his success, even if you don’t like him personally.

item.description: Matt Davies cartoon on air traffic control and the government shutdown.

item.title: Is this really the future of the Democratic Party?
item.description: Will Mamdani or Lurie lead the way? Or both mayors?

item.title: TV increasingly designed for second-screen viewing
item.description: Characters have started announcing what’s happening on screen.

item.title: A welcome consequence of the Tucker Carlson fiasco
item.description: The conservative podcaster forces a reckoning on the right after his Nick Fuentes interview.

item.title: A simple way to end the shutdown
item.description: Rename Obamacare — or suspend taxes.

item.title: Why I choose to root for U.S. dominance
item.description: In a dangerous world, America needs its political, economic and cultural edge.

item.title: America’s land crisis is roaring back into politics
item.description: Henry George shows why rent control and taxes won’t solve nation’s land crisis.

item.title: Biden and Trump, in their own ways, poisoned the immigration debate
item.description: Even now, when the need is urgent, neither political party will seize the moment for immigration reform.

item.title: Wes Moore embarrasses Maryland with his gerrymandering ploy
item.description: The Democratic leader of the state Senate deserves praise for resisting pressure from the governor.

item.title: Put the Mona Lisa in its own building — for its sake and the visitors’
item.description: What might be the world’s most famous painting needs to be easy to see and hard to steal.

item.title: Nigeria’s crisis runs deeper than just a war on Christians
item.description: The Trump administration is dangerously misreading the conflict and its causes.

item.title: Yes, colleges face a crisis. It’s also an opportunity.
item.description: Over two centuries, American higher education has periodically remade itself. Time to do it again.

item.title: How long does covid booster protection last? A new study offers answers.
item.description: More evidence highlighting the benefit, and limitations, of covid-19 vaccines

item.title: Don’t downplay U.S. combat successes
item.description: Readers respond to Post articles and commentary.

item.title: A bad sign
item.description: Michael Ramirez cartoon on Zohran Mamdani and leftism in New York.

item.title: Outside New York, democratic socialism lost
item.description: A big win for property rights on a small island, and a liberal enclave rejects tax hikes.

item.title: The science that extended Dick Cheney’s life was a choice
item.description: The biomedical research engine will create more breakthroughs — if we keep it up and running.

item.title: Elizabeth Warren knows better
item.description: The senator tries to blame the president for a “Monday Night Football” blackout.

item.title: Meta’s misappropriation of PG-13 threatens a trusted system
item.description: Conflating social media content and movies is thoroughly misleading.

item.title: A century-old law could cost these fishermen their livelihoods
item.description: The Antiquities Act is not a superpower.

item.title: Putin’s nuclear threats require a careful response
item.description: To avoid descending into war, each side has to fear the other equally.

item.title: The great GOP migration has begun
item.description: The midterms promise a reality check — and growing defections from disastrous MAGA orthodoxy.

item.title: How Tucker Carlson instigated an inevitable war within MAGA
item.description: Finally, the battle lines are being drawn as conservatives grapple over a bigotry in their midst.

item.title: The filibuster is a wall against a Mamdani-inspired socialist dystopia
item.description: Imagine what today’s Democratic Party would do if it gained unchecked power?

item.title: Neil Gorsuch delivered the most withering questions in the tariffs case
item.description: The conservative Supreme Court justice was tough on Trump’s lawyers and spoke up for a fading Congress.
